awd_titl_txt: Non-Commutative Cocycles and Dynamics of Systems with Hyperbolic Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
The theory of dynamical systems is a modern branch of mathematics which originated from the study of physical and mechanical problems. It describes how various abstract and real-life systems evolve over time, and so it has a wide range of applicability. This project is focused on systems that exhibit hyperbolic behavior, that is, exponential expansion in some directions and exponential contraction in other directions. The expansion and contraction produce a rich and complex behavior of the system, often described as chaotic, with individual trajectories highly sensitive to small changes in the initial conditions. Nonetheless, if a system is hyperbolic in a strong sense it is stable as a whole, that is, qualitatively similar to any small perturbation. Cocycles are a fundamental tool in the study of dynamical systems. For systems given by differentiable functions, the derivative and related objects are the prime examples of cocycles. Another important class of examples is given by random sequences of matrices or maps. Cocycles are useful in studying when two dynamical systems are similar and to what extent and, in particular, when a system is similar to a perturbation or to a standard model.

Cocycles appear naturally in dynamics and, more generally, in group actions. The principal investigator will study cocycles over hyperbolic, partially hyperbolic, and non-uniformly hyperbolic dynamical systems. The research will be focused on cocycles with values in non-commutative non-compact groups, such as the general linear group, groups of linear operators on Hilbert and Banach spaces, groups of diffeomorphisms of compact manifolds, and groups of isometries of spaces of non-positive curvature and their generalizations. The principal investigator will investigate cohomology of cocycles, regularity of a conjugacy between two cocycles, and existence of conjugacy to simpler cocycles. The principal investigator will also work on related problems of estimating growth of a cocycle and its Lyapunov exponents, with a focus on using the periodic data. These questions are motivated in part by problems in smooth dynamics and rigidity of systems and actions exhibiting some hyperbolicity. The principal investigator will use the results on cohomology of cocycles and on non-stationary normal forms to advance the development of this area. The principal investigator will focus on topological and smooth rigidity of a single hyperbolic system and on global rigidity of higher rank hyperbolic abelian actions on an arbitrary manifold.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The theory of dynamical systems describes how various systems evolve over time. This project was focused on systems with hyperbolic behavior, that is, exponential expansion in some directions and exponential contraction in other directions. The expansion and contraction produce a complex chaotic behavior of the system, with individual trajectories highly sensitive to small changes in the initial conditions. However, hyperbolic systems are stable as a whole, that is, qualitatively similar to small perturbations. More precisely, the unperturbed and perturbed systems differ by a continuous coordinate change. One of the main goals of the project was to find conditions for regularity (differentiability) of this coordinate change. This is often called local rigidity, as it means that similarity between the systems is stronger than just qualitative. The primary models for systems with hyperbolic behavior are hyperbolic automorphisms of tori, which are given by integer matrices with determinant one and with no eigenvalues of absolute value one. The PI studied local rigidity for such systems and obtained important new results. In particular, the PI established differentiability of a weakly differentiable coordinate change, and infinite differentiability under a mild irreducibility assumption on the matrix. For irreducible matrices, differentiability was obtained from the coincidence of the asymptotic expansion/contraction rates for the unperturbed and perturbed systems. Further, the PI studied similar problems for a more general class of partially hyperbolic systems. The models in this case are given by matrices with some eigenvalues of absolute value one. In addition to exponential expansion or contraction, such systems have neutral behavior in some directions. This makes these systems much harder to study. Nonetheless, the PI obtained some important extensions of hyperbolic results to this case, and also proved some rigidity properties of partially hyperbolic systems that have no analog in hyperbolic case.

Cocycles are a fundamental tool in the study of dynamical systems. This notion is a far-reaching and useful generalization of the derivative, which is the primary tool of study for systems given by differentiable functions. Another important class of cocycles is given by random sequences of matrices or maps. Cocycles are very useful in studying rigidity problems. The second main goal of the project was to study cocycles over hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic dynamical systems. The research was focused on cocycles with values in non-commutative non-compact groups, such as the group of invertible matrices and groups of smooth maps (diffeomorphisms) of compact manifolds. In particular, the PI obtained important results on regularity of a similarity (conjugacy) between two cocycles. Some of these results were used by the PI to obtain rigidity results for hyperbolic systems.

The PI gave talks on her research at a number of conferences and seminars. The PI was an organizer of a workshop in Dynamical Systems at Penn State, and an organizer of Dynamical Systems seminars. The PI developed and taught an undergraduate course Introduction to Dynamical Systems. The PI has been active in the WIM (Women in Mathematics) group at Penn State. Its main objective is to provide support and information to women within the mathematics community at all levels. The PI has been serving as the Faculty Adviser to the Penn State Math Club for undergraduate students, and as an advisor for Honors students majoring in Mathematics.
